hedline.hl1: 2 Pension Funds Seek Meeting With AT&T Over Stock Slide

abstract.p: New York State comptroller, H Carl McCall, and New York City comptroller, Alan G Hevesi, who represent pension funds that are among largest shareholders in AT&T, request meeting with AT&T chairman, C Michael Armstrong, to discuss company's long-term prospects; express concern over AT&T's sagging share price and strategies company's management is considering to improve it fortunes; request highlights distress with which some of AT&T's largest institutional shareholders have witnessed erosion of their investments in AT&T; stock falls to 52-week low of $28.63 before rebounding to close at $28.81 (M)

block.p: The comptrollers of the State and City of New York, representing pension funds for public employees that are among the largest shareholders in AT&T, have requested a meeting with its chairman to discuss the company's long-term prospects.

In a letter to C. Michael Armstrong, AT&T's chairman and chief executive, H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller, and Alan G. Hevesi, the city comptroller, also expressed concern over AT&T's sagging share price and strategies the company's management is considering to improve its fortunes.

The comptrollers of the State and City of New York, representing pension funds for public employees that are among the largest shareholders in AT&T, have requested a meeting with its chairman to discuss the company's long-term prospects.

In a letter to C. Michael Armstrong, AT&T's chairman and chief executive, H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller, and Alan G. Hevesi, the city comptroller, also expressed concern over AT&T's sagging share price and strategies the company's management is considering to improve its fortunes.

The move by the public officials highlights the distress with which some of AT&T's largest institutional shareholders have witnessed an erosion of their investments in one of the the nation's leading telecommunications companies.

Battered by concern over the relatively slow growth of revenue from services like long-distance calling, AT&T's share price has declined more than 50 percent this year. Yesterday, AT&T stock fell to a 52-week-low of $28.63 before rebounding slightly to close at $28.81.

The New York State Common Retirement Fund holds more than 11.8 million shares of AT&T's common stock, while the New York Pension Funds and Systems hold about 13.3 million shares of common stock. Together, they own less than 1 percent of the company's outstanding shares, according to information AT&T made available at the end of June.

Still, the pension funds are substantial investors in the company. For example, John C. Malone, the former chairman of Tele-Communications, who is the largest individual shareholder, owned about 32 million shares at the end of the second quarter, only about 7 million more than the New York pension funds' total.

At AT&T's annual strategy session late last week, the company's board reportedly discussed a variety of strategies, including an alliance with British Telecommunications; an acquisition of Nextel Communications, a wireless carrier; and the issuance of a new tracking stock. None of these options seemed to inject optimism into investors' perception of the company.

''As long-term investors, we want to be assured that the options are being considered to promote growth and stability in the long term, and not simply to produce a short-term boost in the stock price,'' Mr. McCall and Mr. Hevesi said in their letter.
Mr. Armstrong received the letter but declined to comment on its contents or whether a meeting with the pension funds had been scheduled.

''We understand Mr. McCall and Mr. Hevesi have concerns about our share price within a situation affecting not just our company but the sector as a whole,'' said David Couette, an AT&T spokesman. The company is concerned, too, he said.
